April 10, 2011: Fiction
LIVE WIRE, by Harlan Coben. (Dutton, $27.95.) Myron Bolitar’s search for a
missing rock star leads to questions about his own missing brother.
TOYS, by James Patterson and Neil McMahon. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) Hays
Baker, a top operative for the Agency of Change and a national hero, suddenly
finds himself a hunted fugitive who must fight to save humans from extinction.
THE SATURDAY BIG TENT WEDDING PARTY, by Alexander McCall Smith.
(Pantheon, $24.95.) The 12th novel in the No. 1 Ladies’ Detective Agency series.
SING YOU HOME, by Jodi Picoult. (Atria, $28.) Picoult takes on the issue of gay
rights in this novel about a music therapist who desperately wants a child; CD of
songs included.
NIGHT ROAD, by Kristin Hannah. (St. Martin's, $27.99.) Three teenagers make a
calamitous decision that changes the course of their lives.
A LESSON IN SECRETS, by Jacqueline Winspear. (Harper/HarperCollins,
$25.99.) In the summer of 1932, Maisie Dobbs’s first assignment for the British
secret service takes her undercover to Cambridge as a professor.
THE JUNGLE, by Clive Cussler with Jack Du Brul. (Putnam, $27.95.) Juan
Cabrillo and the crew of the Oregon undertake rescue operations from
Afghanistan to Myanmar.
THE GIRL WHO KICKED THE HORNET’S NEST, by Stieg Larsson. (Knopf,
$27.95.) The third volume of the Millennium trilogy, about a Swedish hacker and a
journalist.
THE TIGER’S WIFE, by Tea Obreht. (Random House, $25.) In an unnamed
Balkan country, Natalia, a young doctor, investigates the mysterious
circumstances surrounding her beloved grandfather’s death.
COLD WIND, by C. J. Box. (Putnam, $25.95.) Joe Pickett, a Wyoming game
warden, must try to prove that his mother-in-law isn’t guilty of murdering her fifth
husband.
THE PEACH KEEPER, by Sarah Addison Allen. (Bantam, $25.) Two women are
thrust into an unlikely friendship when one of them restores a formerly grand
Southern home, with plans to open an inn.
BREAKING THE RULES, by Suzanne Brockmann. (Ballantine, $26.) Izzy Zanella
and his estranged wife are beginning to mend their marriage when they are caught
up in the turmoil of a runaway fleeing a crime ring.
DECEIVED, by Paul S. Kemp. (Ballantine, $27.) The second novel set in the Old
Republic era and based on the “Star Wars” videogame from BioWare and
April 10, 2011
Non-Fiction
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $27.) An Olympic runner’s
story of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
THE SOCIAL ANIMAL, by David Brooks. (Random House, $27.) Brooks creates two
imaginary people, Harold and Erica, to illustrate his understanding of the human
mind, the wellsprings of action and the causes of success and failure.
RED, by Sammy Hagar with Joel Selvin. (It Books/HarperCollins, $26.99.) Hagar
tells of his tear through rock, from his first break with Montrose to his role as the
front man of Van Halen.
MOONWALKING WITH EINSTEIN, by Joshua Foer. (Penguin Press, $26.95.) A
journalist who covered a mnemonics championship tries competing himself.
UNFAMILIAR FISHES, by Sarah Vowell. (Riverhead, $25.95.) A wry look at the odd
and exceptional history of Hawaii.
PHYSICS OF THE FUTURE, by Michio Kaku. (Doubleday, $28.95.) Kaku examines
innovative developments in medicine, computers, quantum physics and space
travel.
JESUS OF NAZARETH, by Joseph Ratzinger. (Ignatius Press, $24.95.) Pope
Benedict XVI challenges readers to grapple with the meaning of Jesus’ life.
BLOOD, BONES, AND BUTTER, by Gabrielle Hamilton. (Random House, $26.) A
memoir by the chef and owner of the Manhattan restaurant Prune.
DECISION POINTS, by George W. Bush. (Crown, $35.) The former president’s
memoir discusses his Christianity, the end of his drinking and his decisions on 9/11,
Iraq and Katrina.
CLEOPATRA, by Stacy Schiff. (Little, Brown, $29.99.) A biography of the last queen
of ancient Egypt.
THE INFORMATION, by James Gleick. (Pantheon, $29.95.) Gleick argues that
information is “the blood and the fuel, the vital principle” of the world.
THE DRESSMAKER OF KHAIR KHANA, by Gayle Tzemach Lemmon.
(Harper/HarperCollins, $24.99.) The story of a woman who started a successful
business in Afghanistan.
LOST AND FOUND, by Geneen Roth. (Viking, $25.95.) An examination of the
relationship between money and love, money and success, and money and
happiness.
BATTLE HYMN OF THE TIGER MOTHER, by Amy Chua. (Penguin Press, $25.95.)
A Chinese-American mother makes a case for strict and demanding parenting.
